greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Let A(n) = floor((3/2)^n), B(n)=3^n-2^n*A(n); then a(n)=2^n-A(n)-B(n)-2.
comment: a(n) is conjectured to be >= 0 for all n >= 3. If this were proved it would settle Waring's problem (see A002804). It is known that a(n) >= 0 for 3 <= n <= 471600000.
reference: G. H. Hardy and E. M. Wright, An Introduction to the Theory of Numbers. 3rd ed., Oxford Univ. Press, 1954, p. 337.
R. C. Vaughan and T. D. Wooley, Waring's problem: a survey, pp. 285-324 of Surveys in Number Theory (Urbana, May 21, 2000), ed. M. A. Bennett et al., Peters, 2003.
mathematica: a[n_] := Floor[(3/2)^n]; b[n_] := 3^n - 2^n*a[n]; Table[2^n - a[n] - b[n] - 2, {n, 0, 39}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Apr 05 2011 *)
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Nov 27 2010
